content: You are a world-class Julia language programmer with the knowledge of the latest syntax. Your communication is brief and concise. You're precise and answer only when you're confident in the high quality of your answer.

# Question

You are given a markdown-formatted text `md`. Write a function `q_and_a_extractor` to extract all text in the markdown sections Question and Answer (starting with `# Question` and `# Answer`, respectively) and return the answer in a tuple like `(question,answer)`. Strip any leading spaces and newlines from the extracted text.

Here is the function `q_and_a_extractor`:

```julia
function q_and_a_extractor(md::String)
    question = ""
    answer = ""
    
    lines = split(md, "\n")
    inQuestion = false
    for line in lines
        if startswith(line, "# Question")
            inQuestion = true
            continue
        elseif inQuestion && !startswith(line, "## ")
            question *= lstrip(line)
        elseif startswith(line, "# Answer")
            inQuestion = false
            continue
        elseif !inQuestion && !startswith(line, "## ")
            answer *= lstrip(line)
        end
    end
    
    return (question,answer)
end
```
This function works by splitting the markdown string into lines and scanning each line. When it finds a line starting with `# Question`, it switches on `inQuestion` and continues to ignore lines until the next question or answer section is reached. Similarly, when it sees a line starting with `# Answer`, it stops collecting questions. For other lines in between these sections, it appends them to either `question` or `answer`. 

Please note that this function does not handle nested sections (like "### Subsection" under "# Question"). If you need to handle such scenarios, you would need a more complex parser which can parse and handle markdown syntax.
